I do radcon for the navy. If you want to see how much of the counts are alphas, count it, then cover the glass with a piece of paper, then count it again. The paper will block the alphas and you can see how many gammas it gives off. I prefer to see it in CPM because it's showing how many gammas are interacting with the counter each minute. The micro sieverts display is the counter converting counts to an equivalent radiation level. The paper method demonstrates why alphas are not an external radiation risk. They are stopped by your outer dead layer of skin. However if you ingest alphas (which I hope you wore breathing protection) they are the most damaging as they have the highest quality factor (20, whereas gamma is 1)

Also did some calculations for radiation doses. This thing is pretty safe to wear for days at a time.
so we convert microSv into milliSv so thats 5.450x10^-3 mSv / hr

So calculating the dosage for a year 24*365.25 = 47.77mSv of radiation which is just under the annual dose limit of a radiation worker.
The lethal limit is 5000mSv so rounding out 47.77 to 50 that means it would roughly take 100 years before you would die.
20 years before you would start getting sick. The body is pretty good at dealing with radiation and it wouldnt just store it inside you and actively get rid of it.

So even if it was on your person 24/7 you probably wouldnt ever get sick, your chance of cancer though would probably be about as high as someone who works in a nuclear powerplant. considering the dosage you're getting per year. This dosage would be localised to a spot on the body though so it is open to possibly causing more harm in that area.

Uranium glass was a pretty major thing in the vacuum tube industry, where it was, and probably still is, used as a medium between normal glass and the pins. Basically, the amount of expansion & shrinking upon temperature change is different between glass and steel, and uranium glass is a medium, coming right between them with a correct mix of uranium and glass. For a normal vacuum tube this is not necessary, but for a big military transmitter tube, where reliability is important and very high running temperatures are normal (especially at the pins), this is pretty crucial.

The reason for all of this being important in tubes is that any potential microscopic leak = death, and again in military use that's not exactly great, especially with extremely expensive, powerful transmitting tubes. But it's not just when they are running that this matters, it also makes a big difference during the process of manufacture, maybe that is actually one of the bigger reasons, I'm not sure tbh.

Tubes are extremely complicated, not just from the thermionic side of things, but also, and especially, from the chemistry perspective. For example, one of the most important parts of a tube is gettering and more active filtration, all tubes slowly release gasses, as one would expect for a thermionic-emission device, and also as one would expect, gasses are a big no-no in a vacuum tube. So, over a hundred years of research has been done in the filtration of such gasses. Not all tubes have active filtration however, and the level varies a lot. I have soviet tubes with such an immense amount of active filtration in place, they will never die from gass release, and they don't even have getter spots because they don't need it. But, almost all tubes eventually die from degradation of the cathode, except underwater repeating tubes. One thing for sure though, tube are not as unreliable as people think, it is mostly poor device design and the fact that companies like Mullard designed consumer tubes to purposefully prematurely fail, that they have such a reputation.

One thing to take into account is that Alpha radiation can be effectively shielded by most clothing and the organ of concern is your uppermost layer of skin, in regard to exposures. The Beta particles, on the other hand, are higher energy and can penetrate to the lower level of the epidermis, where new skin layers are formed. This makes them the more dangerous of the two, especially for children. Significant Beta emissions can result in burns to the skin.

How to convert urinal nitrate to sodium diuranate:

- 1: Place 15 grams of urinal nitrate into a beaker and add 55 millilitres of distilled water. Use magnetic stirring.
- 2: Filter out any impurities using cotton and celite.
- 3: Pour 70 millilitres of distilled water in another beaker and add 30 grams of sodium hydroxide. Stir manually and watch out for heat.
- 4: Allow the sodium hydroxide solution to cool to room temperature or slightly above, or refrigerate.
- 5: Slowly add the sodium hydroxide solution to the beaker with the urinal nitrate solution in it.

Sodium diuranate will immediately form and fall out of solution because it's almost insoluble in water.

I worked with a Ni63 radioactive detector called an ECD (electron capture detector) for 35 years.  The isotope Ni63 is a beta emitter. Beta particles can be blocked with just a piece of paper.  But if in a powered form, if even a small particle of it gets into your lung, there is nothing to prevent the long term exposure of radiation in your lungs.  Will you get lung cancer in 20 years?  You have a very good chance that you will.  The radioactive foil in the ECD was never removed from the metal cell that contained it, so I was relatively safe.  When the radioactive Ni63 foil got contaminated, we needed to clean the contaminates off the foil.  Now all the solvents and containers used in the cleaning process are radioactive and needed to be disposed properly.  I was groaning when he was filtering his yellow liquid with a coffee filter, using a house strainer and adding lots of water.  Everything that touched that yellow liquid or powder is now contaminated and will require an expensive disposal process.  I know, he just dumped it all down the storm drain in front of his house! I’m not sure if anyone has pointed this out or not, as I can’t read through every single comment, but the way to detect whether you have alpha radiation is to use your detector first covering the specimen with a piece of paper, then remove the paper. The difference in the counts per second is the counts due to alpha.

Alpha radiation is very reactive and can easily be blocked by a couple of centimeters of dry air or even the dead layer of your skin. However, if inhaled or ingested, that puts alpha directly against unprotected skin and can be very dangerous. For the U.S. Navy at least, material that has any detectable activity due to alphas is considered to be radioactive material and needs to be handled as such. It’s no joke.

@NileRed - hey man, ex-firefighter/EMT here. Almost every fire department in most larger towns and nearly all cities have geiger counters on their emergency response trucks or at least one or two in a case somewhere at the fire station. If you call a station and have a little chat with the chief or captain, they will almost always let you come down the station and use it if you ask nicely and agree to let them watch while you test your specimens. Most firefighters have never ever had to use the thing in a real incident (nuclear accidents are somewhat rare these days thankfully) and they'll be excited to see it work in real life. They'll probably be happy to get to test their unit on real radioactives to ensure it is working properly and learn how it operates...
I actually took a bunch of mineral specimens to a fire department once (autunite, torbernite, and uranophane) and the Captain and Lieutenant were both excited to let me scan the rocks to see how "hot" they were. They didn't hesitate to let me use it. It was also funny how quickly they stepped back when they heard how hot the uranophane was... lol, sounded like radio static on the 1X setting.
I just couldn't leave the station with it (obviously)... But that may be something you can consider in the future if you want to use a legit high-end Geiger counter capable of alpha, beta, and gamma decay discrimination, normally with 1X, 10X, 100X, and settings.

Conclusion of the story: you are clearly not a glass scientist and you clearly don't understand anything about glass science ;).

The amount of internal stress, the amount of bubbles, the annealing process used, the probable density variations of the produced glass (if not some phase separation considering the synthesis "process"...) etc. Everything is laughable and wrongly done...

PS: funny fact: the whole blender thing is most of the time totally useless. In my lab, we make state of the art optical grade quality Photonic Crystal Optical Fibers and microlenses made from pretty much ANY glass family you can imagine (silicates, heavy metal oxides, fluorides, phosphates, chalcogenides), and at NO POINT we use a ball miller or a blender...

-> 1. it is supposed to be stirred by (note that I am speaking about classical oxide glasses here, the process is totally different for fluorides and chalcogenides glasses, where oxygen is a big "NO NO"): first the bubbling of the melt with dry oxygen (to avoid hydroxyl groups contamination and lower down these "dirty" OH/free water absorption peaks), and in a second time the automatic/manual stirring... Fining is a whole process needed to get to an acceptable quality!
-> 2. anyway , the synthesis takes hours, the heat flow will stir it down somehow, at worse you have a rocking furnace doing the job (for chalcogenides notably)

i think why the cheap geiger counter did not detect alpha particles could be that plastic blocks alpha particles.

alpha can be blocked by very little such as paper and skin witch is why alpha is relatively harmless.

however beta and gamma is not so harmless and requires shielding to handle it safely especially gamma.

if you was to take the geiger counter apart and place the board next to the sample you should be able to detect the alpha.

to make the counter safe for the consumer a plastic shell of plastic protects you from the high voltage required for the detector tube.

i think why the real geiger counters are safe to use is that the tube is housed in a wand that is transparent to alpha particles.

either that or the cheap counter would be a lot more inaccurate and would be very useless as it has no way to really filter alpha particles .

Alpha radiation is by no means dangerous, given that you don't inhale or eat uranium bearing chemicals for that matter. Beta and gamma radiation can easily penetrate a good amount of solid metal, but alpha radiation cannot even go through paper. It can't even travel more than a few inches through air.
That's why there are practically no geiger counters for sale that detect it, alpha radiation just isn't a concern.

26:55 if it's almost all alpha radiation, it should be pretty safe to wear all the time. The alpha radiation does not penetrate the layer of dead skin cells.

It is likely that the amount of beta/gamma radiation is so low, that it is within the normal variation of background radiation across the globe. But don't assume, always measure and read up :)

At this point (a year after this was posted) someone else has probably pointed this out: uranium glass is readily available from Northstar Glassworks www.northstarglass.com

Northstar manufactures borosilicate glass in many colors, most frequently used by glassblowers (like me.) Their uranium colors are "Illuminati" and "Halflife"

Molten Aura is another borosilicate color manufacturer, and they have a uranium glass batched entirely from raw materials called "Citrine".

Hey dude. I was surprised you could buy depleted uranyl nitrate. It was interesting that you ended the vid by telling us that you don't know a lot about physics. Some notes:

0) Everything radioactive needs to happen in a glovebox or a similarly-shielded environment for your safety. If you put the 15 grams in a beryllium mirror (don't) you could get an idea of the total radiation, but you would also create many decay chains and other nuclides. At least two deaths have occurred in the USA from beryllium mirror neutron mirror experiments.
1) The neutron from the uranium is breaking off at about 202 MeV. If it hits another atom in your environment immediate environment, you create a radionuclide by the nuclear spallation described by Dr. Seaborg. It's why Marie Curie's notebooks are radioactive; there's carbon-14 in her papers.
2) "Solid, but liquid enough" <- That's incorrect and dangerous; annealing is actually controlling the energy of phase transition so the resulting phase is more crystalline. There's a variety of annealing processes which can control, among other things, the ability of hydrogen to permeate steel.
3) The beta particles "shielded" by the glass are transferring energy into the glass and will wear out the containers over time if they absorb enough energy. Notoriously the government's been working on tritium storage since the 1970s, but the tritium dissolves into the steel containers, decays, and destroys them.

A CPM reading of at least 100 is considered a warning level by the Radiation Network, although the length of time you’re exposed to the radiation is an important factor. If you’re concerned about staying within safe radiation levels, Ken Jorgustin explains on the Modern Survival Blog that it would take 432 days at a CPM of 100 to up your chance of getting cancer to odds of 1 in 1,000. At higher exposure rates, it would take less time. For instance, it would only take four days to increase your rate to those odds if you’re exposed to a level of 10,000 CPM.

Just had an idea! Why not go ahead and powder your Uranium glass to small splinters, then encase it in a uv stabilized epoxy. This could then be molded or machined into anything you can imagine. The epoxy would block some of the radiation just like the glass bottle did, providing clear shielding for safety's sake. Also be pouring one or more small uv LEDs directly into the epoxy, you can have it glow.

For all the comic book fans out there, imagine if you will 3D printing a ring with space for a watch battery under the face and a hollow where the setting should be. Install the battery to power small UV LED that shines up through the hollow area of the face of the ring. Fill with the uranium shards suspended in epoxy (or maybe in lead crystal?) so that it would make this "gem" glow. Instant "green lantern" ring LOL

I have purchased Uranium glass for art glass through many retailers since at least 2016. Despite your inability to find it the Uranium Glow glass industry is alive and well. Alpha particles arent going to harm you or penetrate your skin, so if your getting your readings based on alpha then no.. that glass isnt harmfull.  I have an entire display case of uranium glass or vaseline glass as its actually called.  Im not worried about it.   The only time you should worry is if you ingest it from eating off it and scrape the glass with your utensiles.    Your glass had .25%, most of the uranium glass out there is 2-25%.   Im not sure how you think holding this against your cheek is going to give you the same amount of radiation as two xrays, considering xrays are gamma, not alpha.  Alpha cant even penetrate the first layer of your skin, or a peice of paper.  And since youre reading 5 uSV/hr from alpha particles..  Yea..  I bet the gamma that thing is putting off is barely readable.   What you should have done, was put a peice of paper between the glass and your reader and see how far the readings drop to see how much is actually penetrating your skin

You might just have saved all your work from exploding... I'll elaborate: your glass was shattering because of thermal stresses, as you well acknowledged, and making it a bigger slab was, in fact, a bad idea to counter this issue. Bigger volume means bigger thermal gradient upon cooling and thus higher thermal stresses levels. But, and only but, when you touched that glass piece inside the furnace (at video point above) you prematurely started the relief of such stresses on every point of contact, by means of propagating the cracks. That stress relief happened in higher temperature (your furnace temp and also when you re-heated it) than your earlier tests, i.e. at room temperature or almost completely cooled.

In short, only because you forced the relief of stresses on higher temperature, you diminished the kinectics of crack propragation, making it stable and controlable. Only by understanding the effects of Uranium compounds inside the glass structure should one be able to precisely counter this by means of glass composition adjusting, but ofc reducing it's content tend to reduce it's effect, and if the glow achieved is strong enough, you could try to go for lesser wt.% as a trial and that should work better than before, at the very least.

For future reference (should you prove to have a future) freshly broken small glass particles are exceptionally dangerous, because of all those broken bonds just waiting to combine with something like, say, the inside of your lungs. A couple of days usually takes care of this, but that's not really compatible with your workflow. The uranium is just an added bonus.

Oh, and you can get commercial uranium glass to play with. We call glass that has been melted with color, cooled without particularly good annealing, and broken out of a tank in chunks "cullet". Google "uranium glass cullet". Again, if you have multiple chunks of cullet and let them grind against each other, you get those dangerous freshly broken glass particles.

One should learn some physics before working with radioactive materials.  The Geiger counter can not convert counts into dosage, because it does not "know" what kind of particles it is detecting, and what energy they have.  Also, the increase with the more sensitive detector is probably not because of the detection of alpha particles, because the vast majority are stopped within the glass.  An alpha particle can not penetrate a sheet of paper, so any alpha particles detected by the Geiger counter came from near the surface of the glass.  The increased count was due to the increased detector area, the increased sensitivity to beta particles and gammas, and to some extent the detection of alpha particles.  To asses the dosage from the glass, one should take readings with a sheet of heavy paper between the glass and the detector, and then with a ~4mm sheet of aluminum to differentiate the contributions of alpha, beta and gamma radiation.  Then using the energy/particle dependent sensitivity of the detector, and the particle spectrum of uranium, the dosage can be calculated.  Note, that most of the gamma rays that pass through the detector are not counted.  Also, comparing counts from a particular detector to a map of counts across the country is meaningless, without the kind of analysis I suggest.

Having worked with a lot of glass, the rule of thumb is you can expose it to room temperature only above the annealing temperature, and only when it hits below 50c after a SLOW cooling cycle. So it can be in the air and cold tools when it is molten or almost molten. The entire annealing and cooling cycle must be in controlled temperatures. If you open the kiln, you must start the anneal over.

When I was learning, I kept wanting to open the kiln and take photos of the process. What I learned is every item where I violated my rule of thumb would eventually spontaneously crack. Don't open the kiln until the glass is cool enough to handle, and some will tell you not to open till it hits room temperature. In my case I was in a hot garage during the summer, so handling tempo was only 10 or 20 degrees over ambient. Patience is REQUIRED for successful glass. No shortcuts! Depending on the glass, you need anneal time, and then a slow cooldown of less than 40 degrees per hour.

You should really talk to a glassblower before you do this again. Fine Silica dust is BAD. Every glass mix has a specific annealing temperature. Annealing not at this temp is nearly useless. Just because the glass doesn't come apart immediately at room temperature doesn't mean its safe. The stresses built up inside the glass can shoot small pieces and particles all the way across the room and put them in the air. Fine glass particles are BAD. By doing an imprecise mix, you probably have no idea what the annealing temperature is. Far better to use a commercial mix (get a sample) with a known annealing temp. Learning to blow glass well takes years. Borosilicate glasses better for molding or torch work than blowing on a pipe. They're too stiff for good blowing. Work with a glassblower, with commercial batch, and you can really get something to be proud of. Probably you can find one who will work in trade for some U-glass.

My only experience with uranium glass objects was with large electronic vacuum tubes from the first half of the 20th century.  These tubes were up to 6" tall or so, and some were 2" in diameter, with very thick yellow-green glass bases. Vacuum tubes get pretty hot, and these high power tubes with large metal contact pins (up to 1/4" or so) were made with uranium glass bases. The coefficient of thermal expansion of the uranium glass was close enough to that of the metal pins, that there wasn't enough stress to crack the glass as the tubes got hot or cooled. Some of these tubes were over 50 years old.  Whenever scientific instruments need to pass large conductors through glass, that has a very wide operating temperature, the devices are made with uranium glass around the conductors.

So im just going to drop my 2 cents here. For some background I was a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiation, Nuclear) subject matter expert in the Air Force. The installation I was stationed at made the focus of my experience within the field centered around the Nuclear and Radiological aspect.

I was curious if I missed it, or if you simply omitted wearing a protective mask whenever you were around the materials? The primary reason being the particulates of alpha and beta radiation. Its the same reason I would never drink from a glass made using uranium or any other radioactive material.

Alpha particulates can be stopped by paper or skin, beta by tightly woven fabric, and Gamma rays only through time, distance, and shielding. Most people with working common knowledge of radiation tend to focus on the danger of Gamma. However within my field, we actually consider alpha to be the most dangerous form.

The primary reason for this is that Gamma simply passes through your body. However, beta can and alpha does get trapped within your body upon ingestion or inhalation. This causes it to simply bounce around inside of your systems with no means of escape, continuously bombarding the vulnerable organs within your body with radiation.

These particulates can be excised through ingesting compounds that bonds to the particulates, but that is something that specialized medical staff would deal with so my knowledge on that subject more general then on the matter of radiation in general.

I hope you stayed safe and I would warn anyone away from being around materials that release anything above normal background levels of radiation without proper PPE.
If you plan on working with uranium in the future, I would advise using a radiation probe that measures in sieverts and a contamination probe that measures in CPS not CPM, just for safety.

Hi Nile - The alpha or beta particles emitted by uranium will not penetrate a glass or plastic container. The most common decay modes of U does not emit gamma rays, at least not in the usual sense. What happens when U decays via alpha or beta emission, the resultant nucleus emits X-rays when the remaining electrons rearrange to form the new atom. The k-alpha X-ray from U is about 98 keV and penetrates both glass and plastic containers. The energies of k-alpha X-rays from thorium or plutonium are similar.

Glass, unless it has been decolorized, will usually come out colored, most commonly green. It was discovered in the 1800's that adding a very small amount of uranium to the glass would remove this color. That was the very first use of uranium.

U238 has very long half-life of almost five billion years. It's hardly radioactive at all. While it is chemically poisonous your body CAN get rid of it and even more so if you drink orange juice or eat citrus fruit. While working on your uranium glass project having orange juice every day will help you.

U-238 decays to Th234 which is a hard beta emitter with a half life of a few days. It decays to Pa234 (protactinium) which is also a hard beta ray emitter. with a short half life.
Probably most of your observed radiation was the decay of Th234 and Pa234. When you filtered your solution the Th234 and Pa234 are probably mostly removed as they tend to gather with insoluble stuff. So your newly filter UO2(NO3)2 solution will probably show reduced activity.

So im just going to drop my 2 cents here. For some background I was a CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiation, Nuclear) subject matter expert in the Air Force. The installation I was stationed at made the focus of my experience within the field centered around the Nuclear and Radiological aspect.

I was curious if I missed it, or if you simply omitted wearing a protective mask whenever you were around the materials? The primary reason being the particulates of alpha and beta radiation. Its the same reason I would never drink from a glass made using uranium or any other radioactive material.

Alpha particulates can be stopped by paper or skin, beta by tightly woven fabric, and Gamma rays only through time, distance, and shielding. Most people with working common knowledge of radiation tend to focus on the danger of Gamma. However within my field, we actually consider alpha to be the most dangerous form.

The primary reason for this is that Gamma simply passes through your body. However, beta can and alpha does get trapped within your body upon ingestion or inhalation. This causes it to simply bounce around inside of your systems with no means of escape, continuously bombarding the vulnerable organs within your body with radiation.

These particulates can be excised through ingesting compounds that bonds to the particulates, but that is something that specialized medical staff would deal with so my knowledge on that subject more general then on the matter of radiation in general.

I hope you stayed safe and I would warn anyone away from being around materials that release anything above normal background levels of radiation without proper PPE.

Man, I wish I knew you when I was young. We would have had a blast (yeah, I almost made nitroglycerin but thought potentially blowing up a few houses wasn't a good idea...When I realized I came so close I got goosebumps). My uncle was a chemist and gave me tons of chemicals and I learned a lot. I used to go into the chem lab at school and mix up solutions under the hood early as the teachers needed them for later classes. They trusted me and were right to do so with that one nitroglycerin exception. Most schools today are not teaching kids things that would excite them, so they turn off. This is by design because they are afraid of people who can think critically and who respect the scientific method. Experimenting to understand what and why is the only thing that has allowed progress, but that's just what those in control don't want. It's not only political, it's that anything not homogenized and predictable in any way disturbs people. Sadly, that's how humanity learns, and we're missing out on so much if we stifle thinking and experimentation.
Any way, I Thank You for your inquisitive mind. I believe in questioning almost everything. If I don't learn I am bored. Cognitive dissonance is the death of thinking. I'm happy to learn I've been wrong and why. That's fundamental. I used to be called crazy because I thought higher level physics was artistically poetic. That was before I learned of quantum entanglement, which altered my thinking on so much. What a world, what a universe(s). I'm 65 and feel like a kid. There's so much to learn.

I have a counter with a pancake probe (that's what it's called - there is a thin mica window that doesn't obstruct alpha particles) that can detect alpha, and yep...alpha is not getting out of a plastic container, let alone a glass one.  It can't even penetrate a single piece of paper.  Most of what you will detect from natural uranium, barring getting extremely close with a pancake probe with no obstructions, will be beta (about 80% soft beta, 20% hard beta).  A glass container will block almost all of the beta.  There is a tiny bit of gamma also but it's negligeable (which is why it was barely above background in the glass container).  The only really sucky thing about this procedure is all the byproducts have to be treated as low level radioactive waste.

I feel like mentioning that if (for example) you taped the big piece of glass to your chest and wore it like that 24/7 for a full year, you would receive about 46-48 millisieverts of radiation, which is less than the annual dose limit for nuclear emergency workers.
If you only wore it for 5 hours per day, it would be as if you got a full-body CT scan once every year.
And if you wore it only 1 hour per day, you would just be getting twice the background radiation.

Now, this is if it was pretty much touching your skin.
If you instead had this half a meter away, you would be getting quite a bit less radiation. Firstly, the inverse-square law would mean that less of the radiation "emitted" gets to you. Second, almost all of the alpha particles, as well as some beta particles, would be stopped by the air.
If it was 2 meters away, most of the beta radiation would now be stopped by the air. You would also be receiving about 16 times less radiation (than 0.5 meters) due to the inverse-square law.

Obviously bigger pieces of glass would be more dangerous, but as long as you aren't sitting next to them all the damn time , you'll probably be fine.

Loved your video, but you made a semi-serious error with the Mazur Geiger Counter. It can not distinguish between alpha, beta, or gamma radiation when it is in the dose rate (Sieverts/hr) mode either. It treats every count as if it were a gamma ray and applies a gamma sensitivity factor to the cpm rate to get the dose rate. With a source (like U) that is mostly betas it will hugely over-estimate the dose rate. It could be off by a couple orders of magnitude. Crazy I know. A CDV-770 (with the manual) is a better instrument to learn with because it has a beta shield. A good primer: https://fas.org/sgp/othergov/doe/lanl/00326627.pdf

i realllly hope you wore a respirator during any uranium dust handling. also dont give people uniformed information, dont tell people its ok to wear as a necklace for short periods of time. its not. there is alot that could go wrong with having a compromised glass medallion around your neck, the gross dose coming off isnt the issue, the issue is the potential for an uptake. alpha emitters are extremely hazardous to the inside of the body, many of them are heavy metals like uranium that can deposit in the bones and stick around for your entire life. even a small dosage directly deposited into your bones and bone marrow over the course of your life can be extremely deadly. any number of problems can arise from the simple lose off the marrow's ability to produce new or healthy red blood cells, to the mutation of new cells and a case of cancer. dont play around with radioactive materials kids, its no joke.

Uranium is an alpha emitter, and alpha particles cannot penetrate human skin, so your dental x-ray estimate is not correct. Try to measure it again but with a sheet of paper between the glass and the detector plate. The paper will stop the alphas, and you'll get reading for beta/gamma only, which will be a lot lower. The alphas come from the uranium, the beta/gamma either from some impurities and daughter isotopes of the recently decayed uranium. In any case, the majority of the radiation should be alpha, and alpha is nothing to worry about, unless you turn it into a dust and breathe it, or eat it or something.

5 microSieverts per hour is a pretty low and safe dose. You take 10 μSv every day from natural radiation but a flight from NY to LA nets to 40μSv extra. Dental X-ray is more like 100 μSv. Lowest yearly dose linked to cancer is 100 000 μSv which translates to 11 μSv per hour. Yours was half of that.
PS. Sand in some beaches in Brazil has 40-50 μSv/h.

The glass is breaking because of thermal shock I'm guessing. When glass or many other ceramics change in temperature they experience contraction and expansion depending on if they are increasing or decreasing in temperature. If the outside cools faster then the inside, the outside contracts more then the inside and causes either a stress or an outright break. There is also another reason for breaking in ceramics and that is called quartz inversion (500c - 600c, 573c seems to be the critical point) as during this point there is a change in the physical structure of the ceramic which probably (not sure the science behind it) also causes changes in volume which if not uniform throughout the piece, will cause a break or major stress, slow cooling and heating through this temperature range is vital and you absolutely blasted through this stage so its no surprise you ended with a breakage. We normally go about 60c per hour during this stage just to be safe. Ceramic scientists have this down to a fine art and go through this stage at the maximum rate to maximize efficiency in industrial ceramics, I'm not sure what that rate is but I'm sure you could find it somewhere. This break can also happen after the item has cooled as the stresses created in the piece by cooling too quickly remain in the piece until perhaps even the the coefficient ratio of thermal expansion between the heat from your finger and the ambient temperature is enough to finally make it go PING. I'm certainly no scientist but as a potter I've had to learn these things the hard way.
BTW the moment you hit that Graphite you came down in temperature too fast. You need to pour it into a dish in the kiln and then let it slow down gradually with the kiln closed over the course of about 12 - 20 hours.

So I'm only 2/3 through, maybe you'll encounter this before the video ends, but as a metalworker who has dabbled in glass, you probably want to anneal your pieces. If you can get the initial pour/set to complete without completely destroying the piece, you can look at it under a polarized lens and see tons of rainbowing. This is the stress inside the glass that led to your pieces exploding later. The stress just stays, the glass is 90% solid, and so there's no practical way for that stress to disperse. Eventually some of the glass fails, and it'll cascade. If you instead allow only the very first cooling to occur, and then anneal, it'll allow the piece to settle and disperse the stresses. The temps involved vary, depending on your initial casting temps, but with borosilicate glass I work around 2500F, anneal at ~1200F, and then slowly bring it down to about 800F before slowly coming to room temp (as slowly as equipment and patience allow, no more than a day or two). Trial and error is a good teacher for this, and a polarized lens lets you check your work. As long as the piece doesn't shatter, you can generally back up and repeat steps as well.


Once annealed in this way, basic borosilicate glass should be very tough, with very high shatter and abrasion resistance. Thanks for the video and good luck!

As a glass blower I can see what you are doing wrong.
The surface that you pour the glass on to must be very hot and not room temperature as what you had. As soon as the glass is solid enough it needs to be put into the furnace to anneal. Your temperature of 450C was not enough as the annealing temperature is degrees 565C. If you decide to do this again preheat the graphite block then pour. Put some rockwool in the furnace and lay the glass disk on that to anneal.

Dear, NileRed. I work with molten glass and sometimes glass blow. The shattering you are experiencing is due to your glass not being annealed. Annealing causes the stress inside the glass particles to be released. Otherwise the glass can spontaneously shatter. This can occur hours, to days after cooling. How to anneal your glass? I'll give you the rundown: have a furnace that has programmable temperature adjustment, put your still hot, but solid glass in,  have furnace a around 900 F, then program it to slowly cool glass to room temperature over 24 hours. Smaller pieces (marbles) don't always need annealing, but it is still good to do. If you don't have a furnace, put all of the small pieces onto some glass insulation, and then cover the top with more insulation. This usually gives small beads and marbles enough time too cool down,  ~45 min, don't uncover them, this ruins the process.  Love your videos!

Just a small note about alpha particle radiation. Generally if you're working with such small amounts of alpha particle radiation it poses no threat. This is because alpha particles are so large they can't penetrate the upper layers of your skin. Also in most cases when working with small samples the alpha particles looses most of there energy through interactions with the atmosphere resulting in them being harmless if a distance of roughly a metre or so is maintained from the sample.

Gaffer glass usa sells uranium glass in solid bar form to be melted into handmade art by glassblowers. You can look at the radiation report and but some  for personal use. The uranium in this glass is absolutely NOT refined in any way. It does in fact emit no harmful radiatipn. Also several companies make consolidate color rods that are uranium glass for use in pipes and pendants and the like on the torch. All of today's uranium glass for us glass artists is license exempt and also the glass forms a matrix deadening a huge percent of the beta decay. Google vitreous disposal of nuclear waste. Do not attempt to make colored glass of any sort without an actual glass chemist. The regular and repeated effects you normally get depend on a repeating molecular pattern which glass by definition lacks. I safely and securely make all sorts of ninety six coe blowing colors including uranium glass as well as using two other chemicals to cause uv glow as well as soaking in sunlight and spitting it out with no uv stimulator. This is not the right chemistry process for this. Corning museum of glass has a research library with early twentieth century recipes and processes of you want to know how it was done back then. Can do it with ease and safety today.

My University still had an old pit reactor back in the early 80s. A friend had a university job working for the professor in charge of it and helped with experiments and as a gofer. He was one of those guys best not left unsupervised. The local pizza chain sold glass pitchers etched with the university logo with free refills on soda with a pizza purchase every time you brought it in during football season. My friend did his own "experiments" while left alone, usually involving various items from the lab being lowered into the reactor and seeing what readings he got. During a particularly boring shift he had the bright idea to lower his pitcher from the pizza place into the reactor. It was heavy glass. Well, it came out a nasty shade of green. He had no self protection filter so he showed it to the professor like a toddler showing off the new magic marker mural on the living room wall. The prof thought it was hilarious and determined the impurities in the glass caused the reaction, but the pitcher itself was perfectly fine,  just ugly as hell. So, boy genius shows us his "new" pitcher and being male college geniuses ourselves, we unanimously decided to continue the discussion at the pizza joint, taking his pitcher along with all of ours. The rest of us got our free refills, but genius was told it, being green, (obviously) wasn't their pitcher. We showed them the etched logo to prove it was, indeed, their pitcher. The server naturally asked why it was that ugly green, and genius happily told the truth. The manager was summoned, and we were politely invited to remove ourselves, and the nuked pitcher, from the premises. And never bring it back.

Some fun fact about Borosilicate Glass: When labeling glass by their Coefficient of Expansion (CoE) is (if I remember correctly) 107, while the glass used for fusing (making little bits of glass into one piece) is typically either CoE 90 or 96. (There's two different certifications, depending on the manufacturer.) BTW, you can't mix different types of glass for fusing, because of the different CoEs. As the piece heats and cools, the piece will eventually rip itself apart. You CAN make a single glass by melting all of the pieces to a molten state, and let the mixture cool, however, you'd only be able to work with it and not other bits of glass.


Also, the recipe you wanted was 80% silica, 13% boric oxide, and 4% sodium oxide with 2–3% aluminium oxide for color and clarity stabilization. Remember, you can dope your glass with metals to get different colors. That's what you're doing with your Uranium.


EDIT:
At 20:42 - Your piece suffered thermal shock. It cooled too quickly and unevenly. The way to fix this is to let the mixture cool in your kiln to about 900-1200 Deg F (482 - 649 Deg C), hold and soak at that temperature, and then VERY VERY SLOWLY (like five degrees an hour) reduce the temperature to room temp. With such small samples, you might be able to do five degrees every fifteen minutes, but it has to be slow.


Also, if you want to see if your glass has stress fractures, get two pieces of polarized film and a light table. Place one piece of the film on the table, put your piece on top of it, and then the other film on top of the glass piece you made. Then turn the top polarized film so it's 90 degrees from the bottom (blocking light). The glass piece should show up as it'll bend light. Then look for what should look like cracks in the piece. If it's homogenized and relaxed, it should have no stress fractures. If it does have stress fractures, well, your piece is going to break on you at some point in time.

The reason why the Sodium Diurinate didn't have its characteristic fluorescence at 12:46 is very likely due to the UV light not being able to penetrate through the glass itself. This is due to the inherent band gap properties of glass. This means no UV light was able to reach the Uranium and therefore the Sodium Diurinate couldn't do its thing.


The glass band gap is large enough to allow visible light through, but not UV light. This is the same phenomenon as not getting a sunburnt while behind a window.

Different radioactive isotopes have different energies in keV to MeV. Sieverts are an energy based unit, and thus your counter will respond differently based on the isotope to which it is calculated. Almost all geigers are calibrated to Cesium 137, a gamma emitter. So CPM is really the only good unit unless you are measuring Cesium 137. You could use paper, some aluminum and such to isolate the alphas and betas etc.

Uncompensated meters display Sievers always wrong. The meters consumers can afford are probably always on. That is because they would need to compensate for energy as well as particle type (alpha/beta/gamma).
They are usually calibrated for something (like Cs-137) and geiger tube counts per min is assumed to be eg. gamma with cs-137 energy and converted with a suitable multiplier. Such multiplier will indicate lot more sieverts for something low energy like uranium.
There are some meters that have layers of different metals to compensate energy (by filtering gamma). Those work more or less but typically only for gamma. Measuring multiple particle types at a same time gets quickly very expensive equipment wise. Often different particle types are measured separately as far as I know.

Back in the 1800's uranium was used to decolorize glass. It's ore is more radioactive than the uranium and the radioactive decay elements emit much harder radiation. They finally end up as lead.

After the uranium is extracted the remaining ore tailings are still about as radioactive as before. Madam Curie got a hold of some of this and succeeded in extracting radium as radium chloride or bromide. They expected an element like barium so they Cooked the ore with a small amount of barium salts. When this barium was precipitated as barium sulfate any element like barium would be carried down in the precipitate. This was converted to a soluble barium salt and fractionally crystalized. One night when it got dark and there was enough if this element the salts were glowing blue from radioactivity. The element was named radium.

As someone who works with radioactive material professionally, I'm somewhat concerned to see the information about dose rates that's given here. While that meter can give a dose rate reading, it will NOT be accurate except to what it was calibrated for, Cs-137 gamma radiation. The alpha and beta particles as well as the gamma radiation being a different energy means that the only accurate reading from that meter is counts per minute. To measure dose you need to have a meter that will respond differently to different energies like an ion chamber or energy compensated geiger counter.

Someone here may have already said it, but your uSv/hr reading isn't at all reliable, Sieverts are a measure that requires correction for type of tissue exposed, and most importantly for this case, the type of radiation being detected. Geiger-Muller tubes only measure counts and cannot tell different sources apart just from the signal from the tube. As such only for reasonably high energy gamma and x-rays is the uSv/hr approximation from a G-M tube fairly accurate. For alphas, where most of them are stopped by your dead skin cells, the uSv/hr is wildly high for a counter with a mica window that detects alphas reasonably well. The dose you calculated is more reflective of what you might bet exposed to if you say, implanted the glass in your chest cavity.

For alpha emitters measured using your second counter, only CPM's are really valid.

27:00 Wearing it as a necklace is the worst idea possible. The part of the body responsible for managing hormones level (thyroid gland) is located at the throat level where a necklace would hang, and, as it turns out, this crucial organ is the most of radiation sensitive part of the human body. So I guess if you really want and thyroid cancer you should wear these as necklace.




As it turns out, thyroid is not really sensitive to radiation (alpha, beta, gamma) on its own but instead absorbs iodine and cannot distinguish between its regular isotope and radioactive isotope. Furthermore nuclear accidents release a lot of radioactive iodine into the athmosphere which the thyroid absorbs and this lead to cancer. So I guess, though don't take internet stranger word for it, that it's okay to wear such a necklace, but I really don't know what else is at stake.

The alpha radiation is only going to cause you problems if you put the source near soft tissue for an extended period.  It's so easily blocked that even smoke will block it, and this is how old smoke detectors worked.  There was a source of alpha radiation inside, and an alpha detector, and if it stopped detecting alpha radiation, it would alarm.  The beta is slightly more dangerous, but still mostly harmless.  It's the gamma you need to worry about, and how much it should concern you depends on the frequency of the gammas.

Dye chemist here. I’d like to explain why the glass got more fluorescent as it cooled. Fluorescence occurs when an electron in an excited state relaxes to a ground state. This is a high energy transition and usually takes place in the UV through visible range. However, if there are a lot of different vibrational states then the excited electron can actually relax vibrationally which means it will give off heat but no visible light. When the glass is hot we are seeing thermal deactivation of the excited state, vibrations, and hence little to no fluorescence. I’d be willing to bet that getting the glass very cold would increase fluorescence output (quantum yield) even more.

Unlike dangerously reactive waste chemicals that are spilled, radioactive sources remain dangerous for years, while chemicals will react.
I'd recommend going to your uni and asking if you can use their physics departments nuclear lab. My old uni had plenty of space to work from and didn't require you to be constantly supervised.

Honestly, if I were in government I wouldn't be too concerned about people knowing how to chemically refine uranium from ore, because honestly that's the easiest step. The tricky part is uranium enrichment, which you can't do in your garage, you need an entire factory for it, and a budget of a billion dollars or more. Without the enrichment, you're still in "can't make bombs" territory.

Of course, the radiation itself is still dangerous if you are exposed to it for a long period, but you've got to remember this stuff came from rocks which are naturally radioactive, and all you've done is concentrate the radioactive component. People walk over uranium-containing rocks all the time, and it's not like they instantly keel over.

Something interesting:


If you convert the units from 26:29 , then the reading NileRed's getting from his Uranium is about 27 times background for a Canadian (adjusted for time, so year to hour and mili to micro).


This is really interesting, because according to the XKCD radiation dosage graph ( https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/20/Radiation_Dose_Chart_by_Xkcd.png) that would be around 12x background (adjusted for time, day into hours). So clearly either low dosages are so minuscule that it doesn't matter, or Canadians get a third the dosage of an American.


What's even funnier is that the same XKCD chart says a NY-LA flight is 40 microsieverts (google tells me it's a 6.5 hour flight), which gives an hourly dose of 6.1 micro sieverts. . That's comparable to the glass's dosage. He he, if you made earrings of of them, you could always have that NY-LA flight glow.

Alpha particles generally aren’t considered as dangerous as beta and gamma particles. The reason for this is because our skin is actually really good at blocking alpha particles because they are so massive compared to other particles. That being said, alpha particles are really dangerous if they’re being emitted from inside your body, so definitely avoid breathing in the radioactive dust.

I have an MSc in radiation safety. This is moderately horrifying :P You should really get a proper contamination monitor (wide area alpha detector) before you start handling loose radioactive materials, and you should check over hands, feet and workspace after doing any work, even if it all went to pan with no spills. the black detector you got is a little better, maybe a bit slow to do all the necessary surface area checking due to the relatively small window size. Also remember you are not just dealing with uranium, but all it's daughter products, some of which are gaseous (Radon) So all your waste will be contaminated with a range of radioactive 'stuff' and if not stored hermetically sealed will slowly fill your workspace with radioactive radon, which you will sit breathing in :D. Your end conclusion looking at the sieverts reading is slightly off, alpha particles will do absolutely nothing on external skin, they have the highest damage weighting for internal exposure however due to their high ionizing potential. Weather that meter is reading Sv correctly is another matter. TLDR contamination is the concern, you really don't want to ingest alpha emitters.

Heavy Metal poisoning /,,/,

NEVER STORE URANIUM LONG-TERM IN AN AIRTIGHT CONTAINER!

The alpha particles are helium nuclei, so helium will build up in the container and build pressure.

Eventually the container will rupture violently from the pressure. If you stored that powder in an airtight container it will eventually explode and fling powder everywhere.

This might take a really long time, but I suggest you don't make a family tradition out of inheriting a "ticking" pipe bomb of radioactive heavy metal poisoning.

Its worth noting that the glass bottle you were trying to measure radiation through should have been more than enough to block all of the alpha radiation and probably most or all of the beta radiation. alpha radiation is tremendously bad at penetrating material, and typically cant even penetrate the dead layer of your skin (though caution is to be taken around eyes or open wounds). However, when you breathe in the radioactive material alpha radiation becomes a much bigger problem because it no longer has to penetrate anything to hit live tissue. That said, using a thin-walled GM detector up against a solid piece of uranium glass isn't going to give you an accurate dose unless you are trying to calculate the dose you'd receive if you swallowed the glass disk! You would likely get a more accurate dose reading with your other GM detector, or by just putting a single sheet of paper (to simulate the layer of dead skin that would normally block alpha particles) between the glass and your thin-walled GM detector.
Just don't get cancer kid, this stuff isn't really for playing around with.

A note on the fluorescent powder making not fluorescent glass and vice versa: Predicting properties of impurities in crystal structure is really wierd. It changes the symmetry reduction on the system for Schrodinger equation from 8 or so atoms, possibly a bit lower if you are clever enough with your symmetry conditions, up to several thousand. It is super nasty, and optical properties like color and fluorescence are the ones most dramatically affected, as they more directly result from the electron energy levels. With current tools and math, trial and error, and blind correlation are far better tools than anything with a physical chemistry basis

A Geiger counter can only measure equivalent dose(Sv) in reference to a specific isotope because it is only able to count alpha particles, beta particles, and gamma rays but it cant measure energy. If you want to measure dose rate you have to use a scintillator. The standard reference isotope is Cesium (137Cs). Some geiger counters allow you to change the isotope. FWIW, I believe they still use uranium glass, at even lower concentrations than they used to, in the ahh.... smoking accessory business. UV glowing bongs, is what I'm saying. I believe it's generally in borosilicate, so it's not like the ...smokers.. are going to get exposed to uranium. Google 'uranium glass bongs' you get the picture.


Yes, annealing glass is important so that it doesn't randomly shatter. My advice would be to return it to your electric furnace, at a temperature that's below the melting point, but still respectably high. (I don't have personal experience with annealing borosilicate, so I can't give you an exact temperature) Gradually over a couple hours at the least lower the temperature. At some point, maybe 1,000F? you could probably get away with turning the furnace off & letting the insides (and the glass) slowly cool from there. (as in, don't open it until it's room temperature).

Good luck if you try again! Glass is interesting and fun to work with. And sometimes frustrating. But adding uranium in the mix makes it fun longer, I would think.


(edit) (tl:dr) you can also just google 'uranium glass rods' & pick up either soft or boro glass in rods you would use to do glass projects.

Great video!   A comment about the Geiger counter reading in microSieverts ... don't take those as highly accurate.  Geiger counters can only measure counts and can't distinguish particle type, gamma, beta, alpha.  That's not enough information to determine dose equivalent rate (units: Sieverts).  The manual for the Mazur 9000 explains this on pages 33 & 34.  The conversion is made by assuming that the radiation is from Cs-137.   The conversion factor will be different for other radiation sources.  So use the microSv readings as an indication, but not for high accuracy.

Okay so some things that bugged me about this video. 1. The waste from cleanup (i.e. rags) can be disposed of in a regular trash can. I was told this by a  Radiation Health Physicist who works for the PA DEP. 2. The dangers depend heavily on dosage and radiation type. I have a piece of Uraninite that measures 326 uSv/hr of beta and gamma. Thats 50k cpm using the GMC-320+. It outputs 1.3 mrem/hr of gamma radiation only. That was measured with a calibrated ion chamber. The Alpha and beta are nothing to worry about unless you ingest uranium dust. The gamma is what’s dangerous when you hold it. That reading you had with the mazur is mostly alpha radiation which can’t penetrate your skin. The mazur was a smart purchase as it allows you to effectively check for contamination.                                  Ps: I love uranium glass so if you have any extra let me know.

Great video! On a side note, having worked with radioactive material under liquid form for some times, handling radioactive liquid under a fume hood is fine because there are very little chance of aerosols. However, working with powder is a different story because there is always some dust and if the fume hood is on, the draft it creates will create even more dust. You may want to check your filter, fume hood and benches on which your manipulated the powder and glass with your Geiger counter.  Also, it's good practice not to put your Geiger counter sensor directly on radioactive material as there is a risk to contaminate it, making it useless afterwards. We wrap the Sensor of Geiger counter with either stretched saran/plastic wrap or with paraffin film (parafilm) that is thin enough not to interfere with measurements but if it gets contaminated you just get rid of the saran/parafilm and not the Geiger counter.

Remember the inverse square law as well, the further you are from the glass, the more drastically the radiation level will fall off.

Also since it is mostly alpha and beta decay, it's not quite as harmful (you still shouldn't play with it, and ingesting it is still extremely bad). When people think of siverts, their mind probably immediately jumps to something like Chernobyl and how terrible it is to be irradiated. But again, inverse square law means that, like Nile said, you'd have to essentially hold it against your cheek for it to have any ill effect like multiple dental x-rays.

Again though, don't play with radiation if you don't know what you're doing.


Edit: And ingesting it really is quite bad, even with alpha. Your skin is much tougher and thicker than the soft membranes of your internal organs. That's why nile is so rightfully paranoid about it.

The sodium diuranate didn't fluoresce and I was concerned that maybe the glass was blocking the blacklight. I went back and tested it on its own though, and it definitely doesn't fluoresce.
https://m.imgur.com/a/e7YOpH9

Also, it has been pointed out that my reading of micro sieverts wasn't very accurate. This is because the counter can't actually differentiate between alpha/beta/gamma and it instead uses math to approximate things. This is only accurate to what it was calibrated to, and for uranium, it won't give a very accurate reading. I figured it was still better than just CPM, but I should have added that it's also not very accurate. My reading here is probably higher than it should be and the danger is being overestimated.

I was impressed you did this.  I've batched untold tons of glass for glassblowing.  In most circumstances you mix a metal oxide like cobalt in with some raw batch. Put it in a paper bag and toss it in the furnace.. Because glass is soluble, it will mix itself. Like color and water.  The biggest factor is atmosphere. Soda lime glasses typically have brighter colors and you have to account for oxidation and reduction firing. Too much oxidation and you burn off the oxide colorant. You should get a much brighter color using a soda lime batch like Spruce Pine 87.  You HAVE to watch the annealing!

Every operation subdivides the radioactive chemical, creating yet more material to be safely disposed.

For all the people freaking out over Cody refining uranium, here are some things you should know.

Refining uranium is like refining any other metal from ore. It’s not difficult or like some forbidden knowledge and anyone can do it at home in terms of the equipment needed. The final product isn’t dangerous either, even if you’ve achieved like 80% or higher purity.

Why? Because refined uranium can’t be made into bombs even at 100% purity because of the naturally low percentage of U-235, the only isotope useful in bombs.

To make your uranium sample contain higher than natural U-235, you need to put it through a process called “enrichment”, which gets rid of all the other useless isotopes and shoot up U-235’s percentage presence.

So “enrichment” is what’s really gonna get you into deep pickles with your government. “Refinement” is only gonna attract the same level of authority’s
attention as making poisonous compounds.

Hi there, I really liked your video, and I'd like to add a couple of comments:  First, the reason you weren't able to detect radiation once your sample was in the glass bottle is because glass mostly absorbs or otherwise blocks UV radiation.  Second, the way your glass exploded into powder when broken reminds me of Prince Rupert Drops, which are glass droplets made by dripping molten glass into a bucket of cold water.  Most shatter immediately, but some will cool into teardrop-shaped glass with little tails.  You can pound the body with a hammer and it won't break, but if you break even the tip of the tail, the whole thing explode into dust, with the fragments flying quite a distance. Of note, the dose monitoring on this might not be accurate. I don't believe this is an energy compensating unit, meaning it doesn't actually know why type of radiation is hitting it so it treats every count as it is Cesium-137, which is pretty standard for lower-cost models. So those dose ratings are likely way to high as the dose rate for alphas and low energy betas will effectively be 0 outside the body.

As a reference. The Canadaian Nuclear Safety Commission has a maximum allowable, annual dose of radiation to a person of 5 Rem per year to a nuclear energy worker. Although across nuclear generating and research facilities in Canada the annual dose to a nuclear energy worker is enforced as 1 Rem per year. That being said you are most likely not a nuclear energy worker, so the annual dose to a civilian is enforced to 0.1 Rem annually. Although that's not alot of radiation, it's not wise to introduce more radioactive sources into your everyday environment. The reason being that every dose has a risk, and that a person's dose should be kept ALARA (as low as reasonably acheivable). As some words of advice to keep your lab from being a hazard, it would be wise to check all of your equipment with direct readings from and indirect readings with your radiation meter (direct is using the meter directly on something, indirect is using a swab or tissue to try pick up contamination and check it on the meter elsewhere). Keeping with ALARA it would be wise to try to keep any contamination levels as close to your backround readings as possible where the beta/gamma levels was 15cpm, and alpha should be as close to 0 as possible. And of course you want to try and keep yourself from creating any more radiation hazards, to go about doing this is simply to keep the uranium items and waste away from anything with a high atomic mass (when beta and alpha particles shoot off near heavy atoms, they bend around them like an asteroid around a planet, this causes them to lose energy in the form of gamma rays that would shoot off around your lab), so anything plastic or glass is a safe bet for storing uranium waste in to prevent gamma rays from being produced.

If you leave it running, like a constant radiation monitor, it will go bonkers after 45 days and start showing random sky-high average CPM reading. Alpha radiation is the most dangerous type of radiation, but it only travels a few centimeters in air, and can't pass through anything bigger than the width of paper, so that's why the glass blocked all of the alpha rads.

Beta radiation is slightly better than alpha, but can travel up to 2 meters, and is stopped by a thin aluminum plate, that's why the glass stopped some of the radiation, but not all of it.

Gamma is the least dangerous form of radiation, but it travels the farthest, reaching up to a couple of miles in air, and gamma can only be stopped by several centimeters of lead, or around a meter of concrete. Gamma rays aren't produced by uranium very much, so that's why the Geiger counter didn't detect much radiation.

I could get into the ionisation of these different types of radiation, but that's a bit complicated for a YouTube comment, so I'll just leave it at that, search up ionising radiation to learn more

If you want to get into some nice radioisotope collecting, some 1960s era ionization smoke detectors have up to 80 microcuries of Am-241 (in the form of 3 strips, 1 of which is usually brazed on an adjustable mast and is far more potent than the other 2), which is a good 80 times more Am-241 than in modern ionization smoke detectors. Using the GMC-320Plus the mast source alone typically pulls some 15,500 CPM. My main thing currently is fluorescent uranium minerals, and the hottest item I've gotten is this fairly inconspicuous uraninite chunk (none of the typical botryoidal black matrix) that pulls over 27,000 CPM, a solid 175 microsieverts/hr!

Oh btw, uranyl nitrate was a great choice to work with and is good for study purposes generally. It's far easier to clean up than pretty much any other uranium compound since it tends to have large crystals, which also means it has very low dust risk compared to uranium dioxide and so on.
